Dictionary.Name: The Free On-line Dictionary of Computing (27 SEP 03)

Definition.WordDefinition:
Exceed
<interface> A tool to display remote {X Window System} applications on {Microsoft Windows}. Exceed is not an X server.
(2001-04-29)

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Exceed \Ex*ceed"\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Exceeded}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Exceeding}.] [L. excedere, excessum, to go away or beyond; ex out + cedere to go, to pass: cf. F. exc['e]der. See {Cede}.] To go beyond; to proceed beyond the given or supposed limit or measure of; to outgo; to surpass; -- used both in a good and a bad sense; as, one man exceeds another in bulk, stature, weight, power, skill, etc.; one offender exceeds another in villainy; his rank exceeds yours. [1913 Webster]
Name the time, but let it not Exceed three days. --Shak. [1913 Webster]
Observes how much a chintz exceeds mohair. --Pope.
Syn: To outdo; surpass; excel; transcend; outstrip; outvie; overtop. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Exceed \Ex*ceed"\, v. i. 1. To go too far; to pass the proper bounds or measure. ``In our reverence to whom, we can not possibly exceed.'' --Jer. Taylor. [1913 Webster]
Forty stripes he may give him, and not exceed. --Deut. xxv. 3. [1913 Webster]
2. To be more or greater; to be paramount. --Shak. [1913 Webster]

exceed v 1: go beyond; "Their loyalty exceeds their national bonds" [syn: {transcend}, {surpass}] 2: go beyond; "She exceeded our expectations"; "She topped her performance of last year" [syn: {transcend}, {overstep}, {pass}, {go past}, {top}] 3: be or do something to a greater degree; "her performance surpasses that of any other student I know"; "She outdoes all other athletes"; "This exceeds all my expectations"; "This car outperforms all others in its class" [syn: {surpass}, {outstrip}, {outmatch}, {outgo}, {outdo}, {surmount}, {outperform}]
